translated: Basket of Conduct
The Chapter on Yudhañjaya
The Perfection of Truthfulness
The Story of the Young Owl
“Then again, when I was
a young owl in Magadha,
with wings that had not yet sprouted,
a lump of flesh in a nest,🔽my mother fed me
by bringing food with her beak and mouth.
I lived by her touch,
I had no physical strength.
In the hot season of the year,
a forest fire blazed up,
and came towards us,

analyzed: pāvakaḥ kaṇhavattanī  dhama dhamā iti eva  saddāyantaḥ mahā sikhī
translated: the fire with a dark trail.🔽It came crackling and hissing,
with a great flame,🔽and gradually burning up,
the fire came near me.
My mother and father, terrified🔽by the fear of the fire’s speed,
abandoned me in the nest
and escaped for themselves.
I gave up my feet and wings,
I had no physical strength;
I was helpless there,
and I thought like this at that time:
‘Those whom I would have sought refuge with,
frightened, terrified, and pierced,
they have abandoned me and left,
how can I act today?
There is virtue and goodness in the world,
Truth, purity, and kindness,
By that truth I will make
The supreme truth-act.
Having aroused the power of Dhamma,
Remembering the former Victors;
Having relied on the power of truth,
I made a truth-act.
There are wings that do not fall,
There are feet that do not stumble;
Mother and Father have gone out,
Go away, you who are born of heat.’
When I had made the truth-act,
The great blazing flame
Went out sixteen handsbreadths,
Like a flame going out after water;
There is no one equal to me in truth,
This is my perfection of truth.”
The Story of the Young Dove is the ninth.
